Had forecasters been given more training and  had thus clearly & accurately forecast the outcome of the US presidential election, I think the book would have become a best seller because so few polling/political analyst organizations got the election forecast correctly.   Had GJO forecasting pages been designed to require forecasters to post 2 forecasts, simultaneously--one based on hope ( what one wants to see happen), and one based on expectations (what one thinks is going to happen)--forecasters might have been able to tease apart their biases from their judgment and post more accurate election forecasts.    One of the display options on the GJO website for questions gives the crowd forecast such prominence that I think forecasters become unconsciously influenced by it, knowing that the research claims that the crowd is wise.  And because leaderboards are based on accuracy scores--how much more extreme one's forecast is than the crowd's--a game of leap-frog towards the poles can develop.  Both of these things lead to the creation of an ever-louder echo chamber. It's a great pity that in setting up the website as it has,  GJO is reaping in terms of accuracy, influence, and book sales, as well as forecaster morale, what it has sown.

What does it take to get on the NYT bestseller list? Here's what I've learned: 
-not every book bought counts. NYT counts only some sellers' sales. Grocery stores probably don't count, but independent booksellers' sales get extra weight. Airport sales may not count. 
-a sales peak during one week is all that's needed because the counts are weekly. Every week is a new race. 
-if the book physically ships out of the book seller’s warehouse weeks before the pub date, it goes from “pre-order” status to “sold” — and thus, it does not get counted in launch week 
-bulk orders are weighted differently. If this book is used as a textbook, not every sale will count 
-500-1,000 sales are needed to hit Amazon's list, and the NYT list is assumed to require 10x that: 5-9k 
-there's seasonal variations, so the bar raises & lowers. January is a slow month for sales; Sept is a high one 
-a ton depends on what other books were released at the same time/what the competition is. 
-the bar is lower/higher in different NYT list categories
~~~~~~~

The main difference between this question and all the others is that for this one, the answer can actually be strongly influenced by persons using this site.  We have little effect on nuclear weapons talks, currency exchange rates, or even election results.  The number of book sales required to hit the Times list is a lot smaller than the number of votes needed to carry North Carolina or even New Hampshire.   So those of you who have friends or funds or both (I have neither, fortunately) can do rather a lot to hype this book and help the resolution become a Yes.  This insertion of an episode of shameless self-promotion into an exercise of some integrity is extremely unfortunate, and in my opinion unethical--at least equivalent to and perhaps worse than making your students buy a book you wrote for a course you teach.  By way of protest I'm picking a low number and sticking with it.  Y'all do what you like.
